example.text:
[NURSE]: Hi Dr. Patel, I need to escalate a concern about Mr. Thomas Nguyen, 74 years old, currently in bed 5 on the urology ward. He’s been deteriorating clinically — I’m not exactly sure what’s triggering it, but I think he needs a medical review soon, possibly urgently.
[DOCTOR]: Okay, what’s going on?
[NURSE]: He was admitted yesterday with acute urinary retention and a history of benign prostatic hyperplasia. A catheter was inserted last night, but over the last few hours he seems to have become more lethargic, tachycardic, and hypotensive. His urine output’s dropped quite a bit — not sure if the catheter’s blocked or if he’s just shutting down.
[DOCTOR]: What are his current vitals?
[NURSE]: BP’s sitting around 88/54, HR about 112, RR 22, SpO₂ 96% on room air, temp 37.9°C. He’s only passed about 40 mL in the last three hours, give or take. His Q‑ADDS is around 7, though I’ll double‑check — it might be 8 depending on the scoring for output.
[DOCTOR]: Any pain or other symptoms?
[NURSE]: He’s got some lower abdominal discomfort — says it’s “tight” more than painful — and a low‑grade fever. He’s a bit confused, which the team on shift earlier didn’t mention, so that’s new. No vomiting that I’ve seen, but he’s refusing fluids and looks a little clammy.
[DOCTOR]: Any recent bloods?
[NURSE]: Yes, this morning’s labs: white cell 14.6, CRP 98, creatinine 168 from 102 yesterday, eGFR down to 44 — sorry, I think it’s 44, not 4, but I can confirm. Looks like he might be heading into an acute kidney injury, possibly secondary to infection, obstruction, or both. Micro hasn’t come back yet, but urine looked cloudy.
[DOCTOR]: Okay, thanks. I’ll come and review him now — give me about ten minutes. We may need imaging and probably to escalate to the surgical team if obstruction’s worsening. I’ll decide once I’ve seen him.
[NURSE]: Alright, I’ll keep an eye on him for now and prepare in case you want to transfer or escalate further.

example.text:
[INCOMING_DOCTOR]: Good morning, Mr. Carter. I’m Dr. Chen from City Thoracic Unit. I’ll just get the handover from my colleague now, if that’s alright.
[PATIENT]: Yes, that’s fine.
[OUTGOING_DOCTOR]: This should be Bed 5, James Carter, 62 years old, under Dr. Singh — I believe he’s the thoracic surgeon on today’s roster. Mr. Carter was admitted yesterday after referral from oncology for surgical review of what appears to be a left upper lobe non-small cell lung carcinoma. He’s had increasing shortness of breath and fatigue over the past month — he’s not sure exactly when it started worsening. CT chest shows a 3.8 cm lesion with no definite mediastinal involvement, but margins are still being reviewed. The PET from last week shows localized uptake, though I think pathology hasn’t correlated all the findings yet.
[OUTGOING_DOCTOR]: He’s currently haemodynamically stable. No haemoptysis or chest pain reported overnight. Oxygen sats are sitting around 96% on room air. Pain’s been manageable with regular paracetamol. No major changes overnight, though he mentioned feeling “a bit tighter” this morning.
[INCOMING_DOCTOR]: Hi Mr. Carter, can I just confirm your full name for me?
[PATIENT]: James Carter.
[INCOMING_DOCTOR]: Great, and I’ll check your wristband… that matches. Are you having any pain or discomfort at the moment?
[PATIENT]: Just some chest tightness, not bad though.
[OUTGOING_DOCTOR]: Vitals this morning roughly BP 132/78, HR 76, RR 18, Temp 36.9, SpO₂ 96%. I’ll double‑check the printed obs to be sure.
[INCOMING_DOCTOR]: Any allergies?
[PATIENT]: No known allergies.
[INCOMING_DOCTOR]: Okay, I’ll confirm that in the chart. What about current medications?
[OUTGOING_DOCTOR]: He’s on regular paracetamol one gram QID, salbutamol inhaler as needed, pantoprazole 40 daily. No antibiotics at present — there was some discussion yesterday about prophylaxis, but decision pending surgical review. IV fluids were stopped overnight; he’s nil by mouth while waiting for the team to confirm theatre timing, which I think will depend on bed availability and the PFT results.
[INCOMING_DOCTOR]: Any relevant medical history?
[OUTGOING_DOCTOR]: Yes — hypertension controlled on amlodipine 5 mg daily, former smoker, about a 30‑pack‑year history, no diabetes that I know of, and no previous thoracic surgery. Oncology mentioned possible mild COPD features, but that hasn’t been formally diagnosed.
[INCOMING_DOCTOR]: So, plan is MDT review today for potential lobectomy or segmentectomy, is that right?
[OUTGOING_DOCTOR]: Yes, that’s the plan as far as I know. Pulmonary function tests are pending — I think they were booked for this morning, but not entirely sure if they’ve been collected yet. Bloods from yesterday were within normal limits — WCC 7.8, CRP 12, renal and liver fine, ECG normal sinus rhythm. No other outstanding investigations I’m aware of.
[INCOMING_DOCTOR]: Great, thanks. Mr. Carter, anything you need before we wrap up?
[PATIENT]: No, I’m okay. Just waiting to find out what’s happening with surgery.
[INCOMING_DOCTOR]: Perfect. We’ll review your results and let you know once the MDT discussion’s finished — should be sometime later today, depending on when the list starts.

example.text:
[DOCTOR]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. Amir Rahman, 63 years old, admitted yesterday with what looks like a large anterior MI — the ECG was fairly convincing. He’s currently in ICU. They started an intra‑aortic balloon pump yesterday evening, mainly as a bridge to CABG, which is tentatively booked for two days from now, but that might shift depending on his stability.
[ICU_NURSE]: Thanks. Can you give me a quick overview?
[DOCTOR]: Sure. He’s still a bit haemodynamically shaky post‑MI, with ongoing low cardiac output. The IABP went in this morning via the femoral artery — I believe the cardiology registrar did it. It’s set to 1:1 augmentation. So far, he seems to be responding — BP’s come up a bit, and lactates look like they’re trending down, though the last result isn’t in yet.
[ICU_NURSE]: Any other lines or support?
[DOCTOR]: Right, he’s got an arterial line in the right radial for continuous BP monitoring, a central line in the right internal jugular, and an IDC in situ. I think he’s also still connected to telemetry, but I’ll need to double‑check if that’s linked to the central monitoring unit. He’s on low‑dose noradrenaline, sitting around 2 micrograms a minute, but that’s fluctuated a little. IV heparin is running for balloon pump patency — pharmacy flagged a possible review of APTT later today.
[ICU_NURSE]: Any communication needs?
[DOCTOR]: Yes, he’s from a non‑English speaking background — Arabic’s his first language. He understands basic English, but it’s hit‑and‑miss for more complex instructions. Somebody requested an interpreter for the family conference, but I’m not sure if it’s been booked yet. His son’s bilingual and has been helping, though he might not be around later tonight.
[ICU_NURSE]: Any pain or sedation?
[DOCTOR]: He’s alert and orientated. No sedation required at this stage. Pain’s reasonably controlled with paracetamol and occasional oxycodone — he said it’s “okay,” but sounded a bit unsure. He’s anxious — understandably — so maybe consider whether some short‑acting anxiolytic’s needed if he escalates later.
[ICU_NURSE]: Any allergies or medications?
[DOCTOR]: No known drug allergies as far as documented. Meds include aspirin 100 mg daily, atorvastatin 80 mg nocte, the IV heparin infusion, noradrenaline, and the PRNs — paracetamol and oxycodone. I’ll have to check if his beta blocker’s been restarted post‑MI; cardiology had mentioned it but I didn’t see an order yet.
[ICU_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll keep monitoring IABP function and haemodynamics closely.
[DOCTOR]: Perfect. Let me know if there’s any change in rhythm, perfusion, or balloon timing. I think the surgical team’s planning to review tomorrow morning, but if anything shifts overnight — especially haemodynamics or rhythm — just flag them or cardiac reg overnight.

example.text:
[CATHLABNURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over Mrs. Fatima El-Sayed, 61 years old, just returned from the cath lab following an angiogram and stent placement for an anterior STEMI. She’s being transferred back to CCU for ongoing monitoring and support.
[CCU_NURSE]: Can you give me a summary?
[CATHLABNURSE]: Sure. She had two stents placed in the LAD. The myocardium is stunned, and she’s currently supported with an intra-aortic balloon pump (IABP). It’s set to 1:1 augmentation, and she’s tolerating it well so far. She’s haemodynamically stable but requires close monitoring.
[CCU_NURSE]:
Vitals?
[CATHLABNURSE]: BP: 98/60, HR: 52 bpm – sinus bradycardia, RR: 18, SpO?: 96% on room air, Temp: 36.8°C. She’s alert but fatigued. No chest pain currently.
[CCU_NURSE]: Any lines or attachments?
[CATHLABNURSE]: she has a IABP via right femoral artery, an Arterial line in left radial a CVL in right internal jugular, an IDC in place draining over 30mls an hour. And Telemetry monitoring. She’s on IV heparin infusion for IABP patency and low-dose noradrenaline at 2 mcg/min.
[CCU_NURSE]: Any investigations pending?
[CATHLABNURSE]: Yes, she’s booked for a chest X-ray to confirm IABP positioning and a transthoracic echocardiogram to assess myocardial function. Cardiology team will review later today.
[CCU_NURSE]: Any communication needs?
[CATHLABNURSE]: Yes, she’s from a non-English speaking background—Arabic is her first language. She understands basic English but struggles with medical terms. Her daughter is bilingual and has been helping. Interpreter has been requested for ward rounds.
[CCU_NURSE]: Any allergies or medications?
[CATHLABNURSE]:
No known drug allergies. 
[CCU_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll transduce the IABP and continue monitoring closely.
[CATHLABNURSE]: Perfect. Let me know if anything changes. All documentation is up to date.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good morning, Ken. I’m Alex, the day nurse. I’ll just get handover from Maya, then we’ll check in with you.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi Alex. This is Bed 3, Ken Harris, he is 71 years old, under Dr Gregor.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Ken, could you confirm your full name for me?
[PATIENT]: Ken Harris.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you. I’ve checked your ID band as well. The cannular looks like it needs changed it has been in for 3 days.  

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Ken came in with an arrhythmia. He had chest pain this morning an ECG was done and reviewed by the team. He was given anginine and morphine for the pain.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Ken, how’s the chest pain now? what is it out of 10? 10 being really bad.
[PATIENT]: Its about a 2, It’s eased off a lot. Just a bit uncomfortable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, we’ll keep an eye on it. Let me know if it gets any worse. 

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s still tachycardic at 120. Blood pressure has been within normal range for him. He’s scoring a QADDS of 3 for the tachycardia. He’s otherwise stable and for monitoring.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: what's his normal blood pressure? Does he have a history of atrial fibrillation?

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: His BP is normally 90/40. This is a new rhythm problem. New meds have been ordered in the med chart by the team after they reviewed the ECG. We're to continue pulse checks for a full minute with each set of obs.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: what time is the echo booked for?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Sometime this afternoon there is no exact time yet.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: okay, i'll chase it up and see if we can get it done today.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Ken, we’re waiting for your heart ultrasound this afternoon. We’ll keep checking your pulse and rhythm and let you know as soon as we have a time for the echo. If the chest pain worsens or you feel dizzy or short of breath, press your call bell straight away.
[PATIENT]: Okay, thanks.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Anything you need before I head off, Ken?
[PATIENT]: I’m fine for now.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Maya. I'll be back Ken to do some obs, soon.

pred_spans.label: Vagueness

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Lars. I’m Mia, I’ll be looking after you now. I’m just going to get handover from Sam, the night nurse, at the bedside.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, Mia. This is Lars Wohler, 42 years old, Room 4, under Dr. Geller.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Lars, we’ll speak about you, and please jump in if you feel up to it.
[PATIENT]: (nods).
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He came in with sepsis with a decreasing level of consciousness, on a background of chronic renal failure stage 4 on peritoneal dialysis. He’s had a full septic workup; results are pending.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay. Blood cultures sent?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, blood cultures were taken—awaiting results.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s febrile—38.6—and we’ve started IV antibiotics. He’s also on IV fluids at 83 mL per hour.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: The antibiotics are running and fluids 83 mL/hr. Any allergies documented?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: None documented so far; unable to confirm with him given the reduced consciousness.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Is he nil by mouth?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes—NBM due to decreased level of consciousness.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Analgesia/antipyretics?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s written up for IV paracetamol.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: And code status?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s for full resuscitation.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: PD?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: His peritoneal dialysis regimen needs review—Dr. Geller will come later to review and advise.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Perfect. Any other results back yet?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Nothing definitive yet; septic workup pending.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Lars, I’m going to keep you comfortable, we’ll keep your fluids and antibiotics going, and the doctor will be in to see you shortly. If you’re in pain, can you squeeze my hand?
[PATIENT]: (weak hand squeeze)
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you. We’ll also keep you NBM until it’s safe.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s everything from me.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. I’ll check the line site, confirm the antibiotic timing, and chart the IV paracetamol. I’ll also keep an eye on temps and neuro checks, and wait for Dr. Geller’s review and culture results.
[PATIENT]: (nods)
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Sam. I’ve got it from here.

pred_spans.label: Hedging
pred_spans.quote: unable to confirm with him given the reduced consciousness

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Morning, Pierre. I’m John the oncoming nurse for the day. I’ll just grab a quick bedside handover from Susan if that’s okay?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: This is bed 2, Pierre Cox, who is 77 years old, under Dr Greger.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi, Pierre. Could you confirm your full name for me?
[PATIENT]: Pierre Cox.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Pierre came in with pain and swelling of the right leg, query an embolism. He’s for a leg ultrasound today at 2 p.m. He’s on therapeutic Clexane.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: How is his pain now?

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s still been quite sore—scored 9/10 earlier; Endone was given with good effect. He’s charted for regular OxyContin and Panadol, and he can have PRN analgesia as needed.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Pierre, how’s your pain right now—still high, or a bit better since the Endone?
[PATIENT]: A bit better, but still there.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, we’ll stay on top of it and use the PRN if you need it.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He needs assistance with transfers with 2 people. He’s using a commode chair to get to the toilet and is unable to walk at the moment due to the leg pain.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: We need to assist with all his transfers, Pierre—just press your call bell when you need to go to the toilet.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: His obs have been normal overall with a slightly raised blood pressure—likely pain-related. The doctors are aware that it is high.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay ill keep an eye on it. 

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s on a low‑fat diet.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Has his meal been ordered today?

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes. He’s still for review by the team; the consultant hasn’t seen him yet.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll keep an eye out for the team and update you after they come, Pierre.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He has Coronary artery disease; and is a heavy smoker. We’ve started a nicotine patch, but he really doesn’t like it. He’s asked to go outside to smoke—he’s been advised not to.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Pierre, hospital policy is no smoking on site. Let’s talk about managing the cravings—if the patch isn’t suiting you, we can discuss alternatives with the team.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Any thing I've missed? 
[INCOMING_NURSE]: No Thanks. I'll keep up with pain management meds and give PRN meds if needed.
[PATIENT]: Okay, thank you.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Anything you need before we go, Pierre?
[PATIENT]: I’m all right for now.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great—I’ll be back shortly to check your pain and get you set for the ultrasound.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Mr Hunt. I’m taking over your care now. We’ll just do a quick bedside handover with my colleague, okay?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks. This is Abraham Hunt, 83 years old, under Dr Jamie.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Mr Hunt, could you confirm your name for me?
[PATIENT]: Abraham Hunt.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you. Any medication allergies that you know of? and when was the cannula inserted?
[PATIENT]: No, not that I know of, it was put in yesterday in ED.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He presented with chest pain, but it’s more likely not cardiac-related. He does have a history of a heart attack five years ago.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any chest pain right now, Mr Hunt?
[PATIENT]: No, none at the moment.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any shortness of breath?
[PATIENT]: No.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s stable. On a general diet, self-caring and ambulant on the ward. He’s on his regular puffers and nebs.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Noted. Any IV lines?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No. Meds-wise, he’s also on Clexane daily.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: What’s the plan for today?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s awaiting the doctor’s review under and may need some follow up tests to see what is happening for you to come into hospital.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Mr Hunt, we’ll keep monitoring you. If that chest pain returns or anything changes, please press the call bell straight away.
[PATIENT]: Will do. Thank you.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks for the handover. I’ll check your obs shortly and make sure your puffers and nebs are on schedule.

pred_spans.quote: He’s on his regular puffers and nebs.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Good Morning. Bed 4 is Robert Lewis, but he prefers Bob.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Bob, I’m taking over your care now. Is it okay if we do handover at the bedside?
[PATIENT]: Sure.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Bob.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Bob is 62, under Dr. Johnson. He came in with a heart attack and has had a CABG.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any other medical history?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Notes say “high HD.” We’ll need to clarify whether that’s hypertension or hyperlipidaemia in the chart/with the team.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, I’ll confirm that in the notes.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s due for MRSA and VRE surveillance swabs.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll collect those this morning.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Ongoing surgical wound care—site looks clean and is healing well.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Bob, we’ll take a quick look later when we do your checks. Any pain at the wound site?
[PATIENT]: It’s okay, it's just a bit tender.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s been complaining of constipation— there has been no bowel movement for three days. Regular aperients have been given with good effect; he reports some relief.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, Bob, we’ll keep up the aperients and monitor for a bowel motion. Let us know if you feel any abdominal pain or nausea.
[PATIENT]: Will do.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: All observations are stable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. Any lines or drains?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No additional lines to note. Just routine post-op wound care.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Plan for today: collect MRSA/VRE swabs, continue surgical wound care, manage constipation, and routine obs. Anything else pending with Dr. Johnson?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: There are no other outstanding tasks from my end.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Bob, is there anything you need right now?
[PATIENT]: I’m okay, thanks.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Alright, I’ll be back shortly to do your checks and get those swabs done.

pred_spans.label: Vagueness
pred_spans.quote: Regular aperients have been given with good effect

preds.label: Vagueness
preds.quote: Regular aperients have been given with good effect

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Mary. I’m just handing over to Sam for the day shift, is that okay?
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Mary, I’m Sam. I’ll be looking after you today.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: We’re in room 1, bed 1. This is Mary Smith, 56, under Dr. Smith. Mary, could you confirm your full name and date of birth for us?
[PATIENT]: Mary Smith, 12th of March, 1968.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Mary.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Mary came in with shortness of breath on a background of acute on chronic renal failure, secondary to type 1 diabetes. She’s on a sliding scale insulin and self-administers her insulin.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Past history includes hypertension, osteoporosis, anaemia, and she has had a previous CVA.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She has a left AV fistula with a good bruit and thrill, and she’s on haemodialysis. She’s booked for dialysis this afternoon and needs the dialysis prescription for this afternoon.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s on a diabetic diet and is self-caring.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s for IV antibiotics after dialysis and also needs a social worker referral.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s it from me. 

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Mary, do you still self-administer your insulin here in hospital?
[PATIENT]: Yes, I do.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. I’ll check the sliding scale and make sure it’s all documented. Any issues with your fistula today?
[PATIENT]: No, it’s been fine.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good to hear.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll ring dialysis to confirm your pickup time and ensure the prescription is in place. I’ll also check the chart for the IV antibiotics to give after dialysis and put in the social work referral. Anything you need right now?
[PATIENT]: No, I’m okay. Thank you.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: All right, see you tomorrow. 
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, we’ll see you soon, Mary.
